overview.short: Anaerococcus species are Gram-positive anaerobic cocci, commonly isolated from skin, soft tissue, and genitourinary tract infections.
overview.clinical_context: Frequently recovered from polymicrobial anaerobic infections, including abscesses, wound infections, and genital tract specimens.

field_notes.Oxygen Requirement: Strict anaerobes; growth in oxygenated conditions argues against Anaerococcus.
field_notes.Catalase: Typically negative, helping differentiate from some other Gram-positive cocci.
field_notes.Shape: Often seen as cocci in clusters, pairs, or short chains.

key_differentiators.notes: Strict anaerobic growth differentiates Anaerococcus from most aerobic cocci.
Catalase negativity supports anaerobic cocci identification.

common_confusions.reason: Both are Gram-positive anaerobic cocci commonly isolated from similar clinical sites.
Overlapping anaerobic coccal morphology and biochemical inactivity.

when_to_question_identification: Growth under aerobic conditions argues against Anaerococcus.
Catalase positivity suggests another Gram-positive coccus.

recommended_next_tests.reason: Reliable identification among anaerobic cocci with overlapping biochemistry.
Useful for definitive identification in complex polymicrobial infections.
